purpose_overview.goal: Facilitate fat loss, improve metabolic flexibility, and stabilize blood sugar through a significant reduction in carbohydrate intake.
purpose_overview.approach: Replace most dietary carbohydrates with fats as the primary energy source. When carbs are very low (<50 g/day), the body shifts into ketosis, producing ketone bodies (β-hydroxybutyrate, acetoacetate) as alternative fuels.
purpose_overview.best_for: Individuals struggling with appetite control, insulin resistance, metabolic syndrome, or those preferring higher-fat foods. Also used in certain medical contexts (e.g., epilepsy).
purpose_overview.why_it_works: Reduces insulin levels, enhances satiety, naturally lowers calorie intake, and promotes reliance on fat oxidation (Westman et al., 2007; Hallberg et al., 2018).

caloric_strategy.note: Ketogenic diets often result in rapid initial weight loss due to glycogen and water depletion. True fat loss should be monitored via long-term averages.

macronutrient_breakdown.carbohydrates: 5–10% of total kcal (20–50 g/day) – Induces and maintains ketosis.
macronutrient_breakdown.protein: 1.6–2.2 g/kg/day – Preserves lean mass without excessive gluconeogenesis.
macronutrient_breakdown.fats: 65–75% of total kcal – Primary energy source. Include mono- & polyunsaturated fats.
macronutrient_breakdown.fiber: 20–30 g/day (from low-carb vegetables, nuts, seeds) – Supports digestion, satiety, gut health.

meal_timing_distribution.meal_frequency: Flexible (2–4 meals/day). Satiety is typically higher, so fewer meals may suffice.

training_integration.endurance_training: Ketogenic adaptation may enhance fat oxidation but may impair high-intensity glycogen-dependent efforts.
training_integration.targeted_keto: 20–50 g carbs pre-/post-workout can support performance without fully disrupting ketosis.
training_integration.cyclical_keto: 1–2 days/week of higher carb intake (refeed days) may support glycogen replenishment in athletes.

meal_timing_distribution.hydration_electrolytes: Increase sodium (3–5 g/day), potassium, and magnesium intake to counteract electrolyte loss (“keto flu” prevention).

supplements_optional: Electrolytes (Na, K, Mg) – Prevent cramps, fatigue, headaches during adaptation.
MCT Oil (10–30 g/day) – Quick energy source, boosts ketone production.
Omega-3 Fish Oil – Anti-inflammatory, supports cardiovascular health.
Vitamin D & Multivitamin – Prevent micronutrient deficiencies.
Exogenous Ketones – May acutely raise blood ketone levels, evidence mixed.

monitoring_adjustments.body_weight: Weekly average – Expect rapid initial drop (water weight), then steady fat loss.
monitoring_adjustments.strength_performance: Weekly – If performance drops, consider TKD/CKD adjustments.
monitoring_adjustments.body_composition: Every 4–6 weeks – Photos, skinfolds, BIA, or DXA.

advantages: Effective for individuals with insulin resistance or metabolic syndrome.
Improves triglycerides, HDL, and blood sugar control.
Simple rules (low carb/high fat) improve adherence for some.
May improve mental focus/energy after adaptation.
limitations: Keto adaptation period (1–3 weeks) can cause fatigue, brain fog, 'keto flu'.
May reduce performance in high-intensity anaerobic training.
Fiber intake may be inadequate if vegetable/nut intake is low.
scientific_references: Westman EC et al. (2007). Low-carbohydrate nutrition and metabolism. Am J Clin Nutr, 86(2):276–284.
Hallberg SJ et al. (2018). Effectiveness and safety of a novel care model for the management of type 2 diabetes at 1 year. Diabetes Ther, 9:583–612.
Volek JS & Phinney SD (2011). The Art and Science of Low Carbohydrate Performance. Beyond Obesity LLC.
Burke LM (2021). Ketogenic low-carbohydrate diets for endurance and elite athletes: balancing risk and reward. Sports Med, 51:207–224.
Paoli A (2014). Ketogenic diet for obesity: friend or foe? Int J Environ Res Public Health, 11(2):2092–2107.
